üß± Why I Left Web3 for Proof of Work ‚Äì Part 2: The Breaking Point

It wasn‚Äôt a moment. It was a slow-motion unraveling.

By 2024, I was deeply involved in a Web3 project focused on rewarding eco-conscious actions using a token system called ‚ÄúProof of Environment.‚Äù I helped run a related Facebook group aimed at building community and encouraging engagement ‚Äî especially among refugees and people living on the margins.

I believed in it. I have a lot of respect for the project‚Äôs founder. His heart is in the right place.

But reality set in: the token wasn‚Äôt trading.
People were earning rewards that had no liquidity.

So I tried to bridge the gap. I personally subsidized the effort ‚Äî offering USD to keep people engaged and compensated.

Eventually, I had to stop.

Not because I lost faith in the mission‚Ä¶ but because I realized I was compensating for a structural flaw. I was using fiat to prop up what was supposed to be an alternative to fiat.

That realization cracked something open. And it wasn‚Äôt just about that project.

By early 2025, I started re-examining the other Web3 spaces I was part of ‚Äî including a local crypto-faith collective and a civic blockchain group I‚Äôd been attending.

Before I say more - *I want to be clear:*

- I respect the people involved in these communities.
- I believe their intentions are sincere, and their efforts often come from a genuine desire to help.
- The speakers were engaging and thought-provoking.
- This isn‚Äôt a judgment of hearts ‚Äî it‚Äôs a reflection on structure, incentives, and what actually works.

One local Web3 community I attended regularly was especially revealing. It was connected to a publishing platform that promised a new way to engage content and community. But in practice, the tech was clunky, and the product was difficult to use ‚Äî even basic edits to content required small fees in a token that few people understood. One of the DAOs I participated in burned through tens of thousands ‚Äî mostly on architecture plans and design proposals.

Weekly meetings had free lunches and spiritual talks‚Ä¶ but the people experiencing homelessness, who we supposedly served? Often absent ‚Äî or tokenized for optics.

At one point, I proposed a practical idea to support a local housing initiative. The vision was for residents to grow some of their own food ‚Äî creating both sustainability and job training opportunities.

The response?

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs do this later.‚Äù

It was polite. But it meant no.

Over time, I felt less like a contributor and more like a prop ‚Äî quietly tolerated, not truly included.

Meanwhile, others held titles, got paid (quietly, maybe ‚Äî but it was hard to tell how), and kept the stage.

There was always funding for visibility. Rarely funding for outcomes.

The problems people actually faced ‚Äî hunger, housing, dignity ‚Äî don‚Äôt care about abstractions.

And neither does Bitcoin.

I didn‚Äôt leave all at once. I still showed up in March, April, and May ‚Äî out of habit, curiosity, and maybe hope.

The speakers were thoughtful. In March, someone taught on mindfulness and the ‚Äúfive dimensions of time.‚Äù It was peaceful. But to me, it felt like another New Age sidetrack ‚Äî far from the urgent needs on the ground.

In April, one speaker ‚Äî a former military interrogator turned AI educator ‚Äî spoke on an AI ‚ÄúOS‚Äù for schools. Another shared how they helped build local currencies in Kenyan villages.

In May, someone presented a trauma-informed housing model for youth with mental illness ‚Äî one of the few ideas that felt truly grounded.

These were all great ideas ‚Äî thoughtful, human, often moving.

My only thought was: they might have been better served by starting with Bitcoin ‚Äî not as an add-on, but as a foundation. Especially the last two.

And again ‚Äî I believe many of the people involved were sincerely trying to make a difference.

But something had shifted in me.

I couldn‚Äôt stop asking: Who actually benefits from this tech?

Does it work ‚Äî or is it just another talk wrapped in hope?

Why does impact often need a token?

Not all the speakers revolved around Web3 or tokens ‚Äî but many did.

And quietly, a deeper question emerged: Couldn‚Äôt we just do all of this‚Ä¶ with Bitcoin?

Without a new platform. Without a fragile token.

Just real tools. Real money. Real proof of work.

The breaking point wasn‚Äôt dramatic. It was subtle, quiet ‚Äî but final.

‚úçÔ∏è A Personal Note

Even after all this, I still attend some of these events. I still show up ‚Äî not because I‚Äôve ‚Äúcome back,‚Äù but because I care.

Because I respect the people.

Because I believe conviction doesn‚Äôt require separation ‚Äî it just requires clarity. I‚Äôm not circling back.

I‚Äôm walking forward ‚Äî with eyes open.

And sometimes that means sitting in the same room with people I no longer fully agree with‚Ä¶ and still learning something.

My break wasn‚Äôt from the people.

It was from the hype.

From the structure, not the souls.

And I still believe we can build better ‚Äî if we start with truth.
